occurrences.line_text: All wrongs haue mends, but no amends of shame.
And saw no meanes to scape, of shame affrayd,
In breaded tramels, that no looser heares
No solace could her Paramour intreat,
No measure in her mood, no rule of right,
No measure in her mood, no rule of right,
His Palmer now shall foot no more alone:
Giue no ods to your foes, but do puruay
They lookt about, but no where could espie
To kindle oft assayd, but had no might;
O stay thy hand, for yonder is no game
In this wilde forrest, where no pleasure is,
And I (said Braggadocchio) thought no lesse,
Yet seemd no lesse to loue, then loued to bee:
And that my falser friend did no lesse ioyous deeme.
That my engreeued mind could find no rest,
On which it seizing, no way enter might,
Eftsoones he fled away, and might no where be seene.
Trust me, shall find no greater enimy,
Losse is no shame, nor to be lesse then foe,
Cymochles; oh no, but Cymochles shade,
She in receiu'd; but Atin by no way
That of his way he had no souenaunce,
No daintie flowre or herbe, that growes on ground,
No arboret with painted blossomes drest,
No tree, whose braunches did not brauely spring;
No braunch, whereon a fine bird did not sit:
No bird, but did her shrill notes sweetly sing;
No song but did containe a louely dit:
Out of her fruitfull lap; how, no man knowes,
Yet no man for them taketh paines or care,
Yet no man to them can his carefull paines compare.
That of no wordly thing he care did take;
She no lesse glad, then he desirous was
And soyld with durtie gore, that no man can
Burning in flames, yet no flames can I see,
And his owne health remembring now no more,
So long he yode, yet no aduenture found,
Found no defect in his Creatours grace,
A darkesome way, which no man could descry,
And found no place, where safe he shroud him might,
That to remoue the same I haue no might:
For lenger time, then that, no liuing wight
Yet since no way is left to wreake my spight,
That no enchauntment from his dint might saue;
Palmer, (said he) no knight so rude, I weene,
But him henceforth the same can saue no more;
And pierced to the skin, but bit no more,
Him answered; Faire sonne, be no whit sad
There is no one more faire and excellent,
Walkt round about the world, and I no lesse,
Yet no where can her find: such happinesse
But Ã´; great pitty, that no lenger time
Soone it must turne to earth; no earthly thing is sure.
And when it opened, no man might it close,
That haue twelue moneths sought one, yet no where can her find.
So that no time, nor reason could arize,
But had no issue male him to succeed,
That in his crowne he counted her no haire,
That knowes no kinred, nor regardes no right,
That knowes no kinred, nor regardes no right,
That in the end was left no moniment
And more had wasted, could no whit dismay;
To be no earthly wight, but either Spright,
No wretchednesse is like to sinfull vellenage.
Vpon his shield, that it no further went,
He gan auize to follow him no more,
No sooner thought, then that the Carle as fast
Therefore to ground he would him cast no more,
Beene suncke, of whom no memorie did stay:
No lesse, then rockes, (as trauellers informe,)
Of that sweet place, yet suffred no delight
No gate, but like one, being goodly dight
The art, which all that wrought, appeared in no place.
Yet that, which reft it, no lesse faire was fownd:
That hid no whit her alablaster skin,
And yet the vanquished had no despight:
Whose soueraine beautie hath no liuing pere,
In case he haue no Ladie, nor no loue,
In case he haue no Ladie, nor no loue,
But when she saw no helpe might him restore,
Who meanes no guile, be guiled soonest shall,
Could find no rest in such perplexed plight,
To whom no share in armes and cheualrie
Thereat she sighing softly, had no powre
O daughter deare (said she) despaire no whit;
For which no reason can find remedy.
(Said she) and though no reason may apply
For no no vsuall fire, no vsuall rage
For no no vsuall fire, no vsuall rage
For no no vsuall fire, no vsuall rage
No guilt in you, but in the tyranny of loue.
Can haue no end, nor hope of my desire,
No shadow, but a bodie hath in powre:
Into her former fit; for why, no powre
No idle charmes so lightly may remoue,
That of no liuing wight he mote be found,
The wisard could no lenger beare her bord,
Hast learn'd to loue, let no whit thee dismay
Yet is no Fary borne, ne sib at all
And ciuile armes to exercise no more:
No whit lesse faire, then terrible in fight:
And fortune Boteswaine no assuraunce knowes,
For she of womans force did feare no harme;
That their broad flaggie finnes no fome did reare,
Farewell my sweetest sonne, sith we no more shall meet.
With no lesse haste, and eke with no lesse dreed,
With no lesse haste, and eke with no lesse dreed,
To her no euill thought, nor euill deed;
Yet she no lesse the knight feard, then that villein rude.
That fast she from him fled, no lesse affrayd,
Tho when her wayes he could no more descry,
But had no powre in his soft flesh to bite:
For by no meanes the high banke he could sease,
Else shall thy louing Lord thee see no more,
No seruice, bu tthy safety and ayd;
She gracious Lady, yet no paines did spare,
Ile clip his wanton wings, that he no more shall fly.
Who no lesse carefully her tendered,
No loue, but brutish lust, that was so beastly tind.
So strong is passion, that no reason heares.
No need to bid her fast away to flie;
That it she shund no lesse, then dread to die,
As it befell, that she could flie no more,
And courtly seruices tooke no delight,
But she no more was moued with that might,
Once hauing turnd, no more returnd his face,
The knight him seeing fly, had no regard
To be no vision, nor fantasticke sight,
That now no more we can the maine-land see,
No liuing creature could his cruelty asswage.
Bidding her feare no more her foeman vilde,
Malbecco will no straunge knights host,
That has no skill of Court nor courtesie,
Such, as no doubt of him he neede misdeeme.
He from that deadly throw made no defence,
Fond is the feare, that findes no remedie;
The learned louer lost no time nor tyde,
No fort so fensible, no wals so strong,
No fort so fensible, no wals so strong,
The louing couple need no reskew feare,
Good Sir, let not my rudenesse be no breach
Of whom a knight, no knight at all perdee,
I take no keepe of her (said Paridell)
As if no trespasse euer had bene donne:
And by no meanes would to his will be wonne,
That seem'd no helpe for him was left in liuing sight.
That he thereby receiu'd no hurt at all,
Or hast thou, Lord, of good mens cause no heed?
If goodnesse find no grace, nor righteousnesse no meed?
If goodnesse find no grace, nor righteousnesse no meed?
Whereas no liuing creature he mistooke,
Whereas no gate they found, them to withhold,
That no man forth might draw, ne no man remedye.
That no man forth might draw, ne no man remedye.
She was no whit thereby discouraged
But more she meruaild that no footings trace,
As if no sorrow she ne felt ne drad;
Hath no lesse griefe endured for your gentle sake.
Who her deare nourslings losse no lesse did mourne,
No word they spake, nor earthly thing they felt,
No spot of blame, though spite did oft assay
For which no seruice she too much esteemed,
Which had no loue nor lemman there in store,
She that no lesse was courteous then stout,
The other no whit better was then shee,
Then tell (quoth Blandamour) and feare no blame,
Wouldst gather faine, and yet no paines wouldst take:
Though now their acts be no where to be found,
Yet from the wound no drop of bloud there fell,
But finding no fit seat, the lifelesse corse it left.
Against so many no lesse mightie met,
For enmitie, that of no ill proceeds,
Which Braggadocchio seeing, had no will
But with no better fortune then the rest:
A straunger knight, from whence no man could reed,
No lesse then death it selfe, in daungerous affright.
But when they could not learne it by no wize,
In no lesse neede of helpe, then him he weend.
But with no better fortune, then the rest afore.
Ne certes wonder; for no powre of man
No wonder then, if that to winne the same
And weend no mortall creature she should bee,
But by no meanes they could it thereto frame.
Her list no longer in that place abide;
That by no reason it might be reuerst,
Which when that warriour saw, he said no more,
He by no meanes could wished ease obtaine:
With fleshly weaknesse, which no creature may
And shun his mightie strokes, gainst which no armes auayled.
Yet she no whit dismayd, her steed forsooke,
Her hand fell downe, and would no longer hold
But no where could her find, nor tydings of her heare.
No longer space thereto he did desire,
Yet was no man, but onely like in shape,
And now no more for him but I alone,
Vnto my choise by no meanes would assent,
That mou'd Belphebe her no lesse to hate,
Is this the faith, she said, and said no more,
Yet found no ease of griefe, nor hope of grace,
And threw away, with vow to vse no more,
But like strange wight, whom he had seene no where,
But to his speach he aunswered no whit,
With one sterne looke so daunted, that no ioy
Yet spake no word, whereby she might aread
Him seeking euermore, yet no where him descride.
No seruice lothsome to a gentle kind;
And in conditions to be loath'd no lesse:
Yet found no fault, but that the Hag did scold
Finding no meanes how I might vs enlarge,
No lesse then perfect gold surmounts the meanest brasse.
But when of him no aunswere she receiued,
Whose will her weakenesse could no way represse,
And vnto Ladies loue would lend no leasure:
But Paridell of loue did make no threasure,
No words may rate, nor rigour him remoue
I knockt, but no man aunswred me by name;
I cald, but no man answerd to my clame.
Whose smallest minute lost, no riches render may.
But by no meanes my way I would forslow,
That like on earth no where I recken may:
No tree, that is of count, in greenewood growes,
No flowre in field, that daintie odour throwes,
And said no more: but I which all that while
For no intreatie would forgoe so glorious spoyle.
No lesse did Daunger threaten me with dread,
But thought it all one night, that did no houres diuide.
But the proud Nymph would for no worldly meed,
Nor no entreatie to his loue be led;
To which no wit of man may comen neare;
No lesse then do her elder sisters broode.
No not the stately Seuerne grudg'd at all,
Sith no lesse famous then the rest they bee,
With many more, whose names no tongue can tell.
It was no mortall worke, that seem'd and yet was not.
I will them tell though vnto no man neare:
But his hard rocky hart for no entreating
He could no more but her great misery bemone.
But all in vaine: for why he found no way
At last when as no meanes he could inuent,
That of no worldly thing he tooke delight;
That it was no old sore, which his new paine procured.
It was no time to scan the prophecie,
And all men sought their owne, and none no more;
All loued vertue, no man was affrayd
No warre was knowne, no dreadfull trompets sound,
No warre was knowne, no dreadfull trompets sound,
Whom seeing fit, and with no crime defilde,
And was of no lesse vertue, then of fame.
For there no substance was so firme and hard,
Mongst wicked men, in whom no truth she found,
And for no cause, but as I shall you shew.
No sooner sayd, but streight he after sent
Who mou'd no more therewith, then when a rocke
But he thereto would by no meanes consent;
Therefore me thither lead. No more he spake,
He saw no way, but close with him in hast;
And then no ods at all in him he fownd:
That his faint foe no longer could abide
Long they her sought, yet no where could they finde her,
Yet for no pitty would he change the course
That there mote be no hope of reparation,
And mongst them al no change hath yet beene found.
I will suppresse, that they no more may raine;
Doe eate the earth, it is no more at all:
And by no meane could in the weight be stayd.
For by no meanes the false will with the truth be wayd.
As by no meanes he can himselfe outwind.
He could no longer beare, but forth issewed,
Such power it had, that to no womans wast
Which Artegall well hearing, though no more
Whereof no brauer president this day
But whether it be so or no, I can not say.
But whether it indeede be so or no,
Dismayd so with the stroke, that he no colours knew.
Could take no rest, ne would receiue reliefe,
No hand so cruell, nor no hart so hard,
No hand so cruell, nor no hart so hard,
No fayrer conquest, then that with goodwill is gayned.
It is no lesse beseeming well, to beare
But by no meanes could her thereto perswade:
That no new loues impression euer could
Yet loth she was, since she no ill did heare,
Yet found no place, that could her liking please,
Yet found no easement in her troubled wits,
As by his modest semblant, that no euill ment.
He list no lenger to vse lothfull speach,
The loft was raysd againe, that no man could it spie.
No more shall now the darkenesse of the night
And would no lenger treat, but bad them sound.
For her no other termes should euer tie
That he no worke at all left for the leach:
Whom like disguize no lesse deformed had,
Which vaine conceipt now nourishing no more,
And lastly, that no shame might wanting be,
The resty raynes, regarded now no more:
No easie meanes according to his mind.
That no whole peece of him was to be seene,
That of his shape appear'd no litle moniment.
With her, to see her Ladie thence no farre away.
A dreadfull depth, how deepe no man can tell;
And reasons brought, that no man could refute;
The woefull widow had no meanes now left,
So that no whit of them remayning one may see.
Yet could the Seneschals no entrance find
Long sought the Prince, but when he found no more
To which they had no right, nor any wrongfull state.
It would no passage yeeld vnto his purpose vaine.
Thenceforth he car'd no more, which way he strooke,
Most richly made, but there no Monster did behold.
That he had red her Riddle, which no wight
By which if that no champion doe appeare,
Gainst which the pallid death findes no defence.
Yet rescue her thence by no meanes I may:
Gainst which no flight nor rescue mote auayle,
Vpon his steede, whiles she no whit gainesayd,
No faith so firme, no trust can be so strong,
No faith so firme, no trust can be so strong,
No loue so lasting then, that may enduren long.
And so be now Grantorto, who no lesse
Sith no redemption nigh she did nor heare nor see.
No shame to stoupe, ones head more high to reare,
Which thereon seizing, tooke no great effect;
That by no meanes it backe againe he forth could wrast.
Which Artegall perceiuing, strooke no more,
Yet he past on, and seem'd of them to take no keepe.
When he him saw, for no demaunds he staide,
For may no Knight nor Lady passe along
When as the Carle no longer could sustaine,
False traytor Knight, (sayd she) no Knight at all,
Bloud is no blemish; for it is no blame
Bloud is no blemish; for it is no blame
No greater shame to man then inhumanitie.
(Quoth he) I hold it no indignity;
Yet no whit more appalled for the same,
Strangers no more so rudely to intreat,
By thee no knight; which armes impugneth plaine?
Which I no lesse disdayning, backe returned
But when as her he by no meanes could find,
Vpon his steed, for no iust cause accused,
Into some forrein land, where as no need
Into the land of Faerie, where no wight
I should no creature ioyne vnto mine ayde,
And to her said; Dame be no longer sad:
Would to no bed, nor take no kindely sleepe,
Would to no bed, nor take no kindely sleepe,
Or had no courage, or else had no gall.
Or had no courage, or else had no gall.
That him to no reuenge he forth could call,
But the rude Porter that no manners had,
Who to him aunswer'd, that there was no place
Yet had no meanes to comfort, nor procure her glee.
But all in vaine; for why, no remedy
No more then for the stroke of strawes or bents:
Yet in his bodie made no wound nor bloud appeare.
And held the same so hard, that by no wize
Who hauing now no vse of his long speare,
Yet now no lesse encombrance she did see,
Gainst whom she saw no meanes to be defended,
But that same Ladies hurts no herbe he found,
But the bold knight no whit thereat dismayd,
He could no path nor tract of foot descry,
He sought him farre and neare, yet him no where he spyde.
At length, when as no hope of his retourne
That no one beast in forrest wylde or tame,
The couert was so thicke, that did no passage shew.
But faire Serene all night could take no rest,
No wound, which warlike hand of enemy
For by no art, nor any leaches might
If that no salues may vs to health restore?
Yet for no bidding, nor for being shent,
As one that had no life him left through former feare.
Fayles of her souse, and passing by doth hurt no more.
But the steele-head no stedfast hold could fynd,
For wheres no courage, theres no ruth nor mone.
For wheres no courage, theres no ruth nor mone.
Whilest she did weepe, of no man mercifide.
Of whom what was becomen, no man knew.
He wore no armour, ne for none did care,
As no whit dreading any liuing wight;
And could no lenger beare so great abuse,
No more then lightening from the lofty sky.
It crackt throughout, yet did no bloud appeare;
That, were no might in man, nor heart in Knights,
With these two lewd companions, and no more,
For were no law in loue, but all that lust,
Yet no lesse thankes to you for your good will.
They answer'd him, that no such beast they saw,
The knight was nothing nice, where was no need,
Doe them afflict, which no man can appease,
No better doe I weare, no better doe I feed.
No better doe I weare, no better doe I feed.
Me no such cares nor combrous thoughts offend,
And other, that hath litle, askes no more,
Yet she no whit his presents did regard,
That from henceforth he meanes no more to sew
But Calidore, though no lesse sory wight,
Whom by no meanes thou canst recall againe;
That thence, he had no will away to fare,
Which to recure, no skill of Leaches art
He had no weapon, but his shepheards hooke,
Couered with shrubby woods, in which no way
Through hollow caues, that no man mote discouer
For slaues to sell them, for no small reward,
Like to a flowre, that feeles no heate of sunne,
That here on earth is no sure happinesse,
She found no meanes to barre him, but to faine
But she resolu'd no remedy to fynde,
Out quenched, leaues no skill nor difference of wight.
He sought the woods; but no man could see there;
He sought the plaines; but could no tydings heare.
That he no word could speake, but smit his brest,
Tho when no more could nigh to him approch,
No lesse did tender the faire Pastorell,
The matrone stayd no lenger to enquire,
Who now no place besides vnsought had left,
But Calidore thereof no whit afrayd,
And chauffed inly, seeing now no more
Prince Arthur, flowre of grace and nobilesse,
Him his nobilitie so foule deface;
And titles of nobilitie deface:
Then came Nobilitie of birth, that bread
Yet brancheth forth in braue nobilitie,
Her nourced had in trew Nobility:
Whom that most noble Briton Prince so long
Both for her noble bloud, and for her tender youth.
But he my Lyon, and my noble Lord,
Like euer saw. And there a noble crew
And him rencountring fierce, reskewd the noble pray.
The noble hart, that harbours vertuous thought,
It fortuned a noble warlike knight
Where she had left, the noble Redcrosse knight,
Haue thither come the noble Martiall crew,
That noble order hight of Maidenhed,
The noble knight alighted by and by
But wise and warie was that noble Pere,
When as the noble Prince had marked well,
And noble minds of yore allyed were,
And goodly gan discourse of many a noble gest.
And well beseemes all knights of noble name,
The sparke of noble courage now awake,
A noble crew about them waited round
By dew desert of noble cheualree,
He was an Elfin borne of noble state,
That you, most noble Sir, had present beene,
Or fell Erinnys, in your noble harts
His puissaunt armes about his noble brest,
And noble worth to be aduaunced hye:
Betweene the vulgar and the noble seed,
The noble Guyon mou'd with great remorse,
The which was borne of noble parentage,
That him so noble knight had maistered,
Helpe, Ã´ Sir Guyon, helpe most noble knight,
Ah well away, most noble Lords, how can
That noble heart as great dishonour doth despize.
That many noble Greekes and Troians made to bleed.
Ne was there euer noble courage seene,
Said Guyon, Noble Lord, what meed so great,
And many a Lord of noble parentage,
Goodly she entertaind those noble knights,
Whose noble deedes aboue the Northerne starre
The noble daughter of Corineus
With noble deedes, and warreyd on Brunchild
The noble braunch from th'antique stocke was torne
Next him was noble Elfinan, who layd
And fairely feasted, as so noble knights she ought.
The noble virgin, Ladie of the place,
Then forth the noble Guyon sallied,
The noble Elfe, and carefull Palmer drew
Let later age that noble vse enuie,
The noble Britomartis her arayd,
The noble Arthegall hath euer borne the name.
The noble courage neuer weeneth ought,
Ne ought it mote the noble Mayd auayle,
Whence spring all noble deeds and neuer dying fame:
Most noble Virgin, that by fatall lore
Cannot with noble Britomart compare,
That through all Farie lond his noble fame
Her noble deeds, ne her right course for ought forsooke.
Of his hard hap did vexe his noble brest,
Euer to creepe into his noble brest,
As meetest may beseeme a noble mayd;
For whiles his Lord pursewd that noble Mayd,
How that a noble hunteresse did wonne,
Ye wonder, how this noble Damozell
Of grace and beautie noble Paragone,
Saue to the noble knight Sir Scudamore,
He neare was touched in his noble spright,
That all the noble knights of Maydenhead,
Her noble bloud? the heauens such crueltie abhore.
Ye noble knights (said then the Squire of Dames)
And noble prowesse, which they had approued,
Sir Paris far renowmd through noble fame,
With carcases of noble warrioures,
Whenas the noble Britomart heard tell
For noble Britons sprong from Troians bold,
Of straunge affaires, and noble hardiment,
Then now, that noble succour is thee by,
And you most noble Lord, that can and dare
She was emmoued in her noble mind,
